messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Last-iterate Convergence of Decentralized Optimistic Gradient Descent/Ascent in Infinite-horizon Competitive Markov Games

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study infinite-horizon discounted two-player zero-sum Markov games, and develop a decentralized algorithm that provably converges to the set of Nash equilibria under self-play. Our algorithm is based on running an Optimistic Gradient Descent Ascent algorithm on each state to learn the policies, with a critic that slowly learns the value of each state. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first algorithm in this setting that is simultaneously rational (converging to the opponent‚Äôs best response when it uses a stationary policy), convergent (converging to the set of Nash equilibria under self-play), agnostic (no need to know the actions played by the opponent), symmetric (players taking symmetric roles in the algorithm), and enjoying a finite-time last-iterate convergence guarantee, all of which are desirable properties of decentralized algorithms.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Politex: Regret bounds for policy iteration using expert prediction",
        "On the theory of policy gradient methods: Optimality, approximation, and distribution shift",
        "Logarithmic online regret bounds for undiscounted reinforcement learning",
        "Provable self-play algorithms for competitive reinforcement learning",
        "Near-optimal reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "Rational and convergent learning in stochastic games",
        "R-max-a general polynomial time algorithm for near-optimal reinforcement learning",
        "Online optimization with gradual variations",
        "Awesome: A general multiagent learning algorithm that converges in self-play and learns a best response against stationary opponents",
        "Independent policy gradient methods for competitive reinforcement learning",
        "Competitive Markov decision processes",
        "On the algorithm of pollatschek and avi-ltzhak",
        "First-order algorithm with ùí™‚Äã(ln‚Å°(1/œµ))ùí™1italic-œµ\\mathcal{O}(\\ln(1/\\epsilon)) convergence for œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon-equilibrium in two-person zero-sum games",
        "Tight last-iterate convergence rates for no-regret learning in multi-player games",
        "On nonterminating stochastic games",
        "On the convergence of single-call stochastic extra-gradient methods",
        "Is q-learning provably efficient?",
        "Linear last-iterate convergence for matrix games and stochastic games",
        "Interaction matters: A note on non-asymptotic local convergence of generative adversarial networks",
        "Markov games as a framework for multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Policy optimization in zero-sum markov games: Fictitious self-play provably attains nash equilibria, 2020",
        "A sharp analysis of model-based reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "A unified analysis of extra-gradient and optimistic gradient methods for saddle point problems: Proximal point approach",
        "Approximate dynamic programming for two-player zero-sum markov games",
        "Softened approximate policy iteration for markov games",
        "Actor-critic fictitious play in simultaneous move multistage games",
        "Algorithms for stochastic games with geometrical interpretation",
        "A modification of the arrow-hurwicz method for search of saddle points",
        "Learning to collaborate in markov decision processes",
        "Optimization, learning, and games with predictable sequences",
        "Fictitious play in zero-sum stochastic games",
        "Stochastic games",
        "Solving discounted stochastic two-player games with near-optimal time and sample complexity",
        "Mastering the game of go without human knowledge",
        "Fast convergence of regularized learning in games",
        "A unified analysis of value-function-based reinforcement-learning algorithms",
        "Online learning in unknown markov games",
        "Discounted markov games: Generalized policy iteration method",
        "Grandmaster level in starcraft ii using multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Online reinforcement learning in stochastic games",
        "Linear last-iterate convergence in constrained saddle-point optimization",
        "Learning zero-sum simultaneous-move markov games using function approximation and correlated equilibrium",
        "Policy optimization provably converges to nash equilibria in zero-sum linear quadratic games",
        "Model-based multi-agent rl in zero-sum markov games with near-optimal sample complexity",
        "Multi-agent reinforcement learning: A selective overview of theories and algorithms"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Last-iterate Convergence of Decentralized Optimistic Gradient Descent/Ascent in Infinite-horizon Competitive Markov Games, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
